TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine-loamy over sandy or sandy-skeletal, mixed, superactive, mesic Aquic Haplargids

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Wardwell loam, cultivated.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
Ap--0 to 7 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) and light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) light loam, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) moist; few very faint mottles; weak very fine  granular structure; slightly hard, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common fine roots; many very fine pores; (pH 6.0); abrupt smooth boundary.  (4 to 8inches thick)
A21--7 to 10 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) and light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) loam, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) moist; few fine faint light gray (10YR 7/2) mottles; massive; hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common fine roots; many very fine and fine pores; slightly acid (pH 6.1); clear smooth boundary.  (2 to 5 inches thick)
A22--10 to 12 inches; light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) and pale brown (10YR 6/3) loam, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) moist; few fine distinct yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) mottles, dark yellowish brown (10YR 3/4) moist; few medium faint light gray (2.5Y 7/2) mottles, grayish brown (10YR 5/2) moist; massive; hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common fine roots; many very fine and fine pores; slightly acid (pH 6.0); clear smooth boundary.  (1 to 3 inches thick)
B2t--12 to 17 inches; light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) heavy loam containing about twice as much clay as the Ap, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) moist; few fine distinct brown (10YR 5/3) mottles, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; weak fine medium prismatic structure parting to moderate medium subangular and angular blocky; very hard, firm, sticky and plastic; few fine roots; few very fine pores; continuous thin dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) clay films on surfaces of peds which  are very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; slightly acid (pH 6.3); clear smooth boundary.  (4 to 9 inches thick)
B3ca--17 to 34 inches; light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) loam, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) moist; common coarse faint pale brown (10YR 6/3) mottles; and few fine distinct dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist mottles; weak fine and subangular blocky structure; very hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; few fine roots; common very fine pores; moderately calcareous with few fine lime veins and splotches; mildly alkaline (pH 7.6); clear smooth boundary.  (5 to 10 inches thick)
IIC1--24 to 32 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) fine sandy loam, brown (10YR 4/3) moist; common medium faint light gray (10YR 7/2) mottles, grayish brown (10YR 5/2) moist; massive; hard, very friable, slightly sticky and nonplastic; few fine roots; many very fine pores; slightly calcareous; mildly alkaline (pH 7.8); abrupt smooth boundary.  (0 to 20 inches thick)
IIIC2--32 inches; loose gravel and sand.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Gem County, Idaho; i mile east of Emmett; 50 feet north and 80 feet west of the center of the SE1/4 section 5, T.6N., R.1W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The mean annual soil temperature ranges from 47 to 53 degrees F.  The soils are usually dry but unless artificially drained they are saturated in a subhorizon between depths of 24 to 40 inches for a short period in late summer and have dominant chroma of 2 or less accompanied by mottles due to segregation of iron or manganese within depth of 40 inches.  Solum thickness is 16 to 30 inches and depth to moderately or slightly calcareous B3ca horizon is 12 to 20 inches.  Depth to loose sand and gravel is 20 to 40 inches.
The A horizon has hue of 10YR or 2.5Y, value of 5 or 6 dry, 3 or 4 moist, and chroma of 2 or 3.  Any surface layer having value darker than 5.5 dry and 3.5 moist is less than 7 inches thick.  Texture is typically loam, but ranges to fine sandy loam.  Reaction is medium acid to mildly alkaline.
The B2t horizon is loam, sandy clay loam, or clay loam.  It has weak or moderate prismatic or moderate strong subangular blocky structure.  This horizon averages 17 to 34 percent clay.  Reaction is slightly acid to mildly alkaline.
The C horizon is neutral to moderately alkaline.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Abo, Bramwell, and Lamanga series.  These soils lack contrasting textures above depth of 40 inches.  Bramwell soils are moderately or strongly calcareous.  Lamanga soils have frigid temperature.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Wardwell soils are on low stream terraces and have slopes of 0 to 2 percent.  The soils formed in alluvium mainly from intrusive acid igneous rock sources.  Elevations are 2,000 to 2,500 feet.  The climate has hot, dry summers and cold, moist winters.  The mean annual precipitation is 8 to 12 inches.  The mean summer temperature is 70 to 72 degrees F., and the mean annual temperature is about 48 to 52 degrees F.  The frost free season is about 145 to 170 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Bissel, Emerson, Falk, Letha and Quenzer soils and the competing Bramwell soils.  Bissell soils lack mottles above depth of 40 inches.  Emerson and Falk soils lack argillic horizons.  Letha soils have sodium saturation greater than 50 percent in the upper 20 inches.  Quenzer soils lack argillic horizons and are gleyed throughout the profile.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Somewhat poorly drained; slow or medium runoff; moderately slow permeability.  A water table is common between depths of 30 and 60 inches.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used for irrigated hay, pasture, corn, wheat and barley.  Natural vegetation is bunchgrasses, sedges, rushes and other moisture loving plants.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Southwstern Idaho.  The soil is inextensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Portland, Oregon

ORIGIN.content:
SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Gem County, Idaho, 1948.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U. S. A.
